case_study.title: Case Study: The Two Policies
case_study.scenario: A company owns a building worth £1 million. It has two separate fire insurance policies on the building: one with Insurer A for a sum insured of £750,000 and another with Insurer B for a sum insured of £500,000. A fire causes £100,000 of damage. The company claims the full £100,000 from Insurer A, as the loss is well within their sum insured.

questions.question: Can the company claim the full £100,000 from Insurer A? What right does Insurer A have?
questions.answer: Yes, in the absence of a specific policy condition, the company can claim the full amount from either insurer. However, Insurer A has the right of contribution. This allows them to call upon Insurer B to share the cost of the claim, as both policies cover the same interest, subject-matter, and peril.

questions.question: How will the two insurers share the £100,000 loss?
questions.answer: They will share it in proportion to their sums insured. The total sum insured is £1,250,000 (£750,000 + £500,000). Insurer A's share is (£750,000 / £1,250,000) = 60%. Insurer B's share is (£500,000 / £1,250,000) = 40%. Therefore, Insurer A will pay £60,000 and can recover £40,000 from Insurer B.

questions.question: For the principle of contribution to apply, which of the following conditions is NOT required?
options: The policies must have identical sums insured.
The policies must cover a common insurable interest.
The policies must cover a common peril that caused the loss.
Each policy must be a contract of indemnity.
questions.correctAnswer: The policies must have identical sums insured.
questions.explanation: For contribution to apply, five conditions are needed: 1) Two or more policies of indemnity; 2) Common insurable interest; 3) Common peril; 4) Common subject-matter; 5) Each policy must be liable for the loss. The sums insured do not need to be identical.

questions.question: Under contribution, insurers typically share the loss:
options: In proportion to their respective sums insured
By who issued the earliest policy
questions.correctAnswer: In proportion to their respective sums insured
questions.explanation: Rateable proportion is the standard approach unless modified by wording.

questions.question: A 'non-contribution' clause in one policy usually means:
options: That policy avoids any share where another policy exists
The clause is illegal and void
questions.correctAnswer: That policy avoids any share where another policy exists
questions.explanation: Wording can disapply contribution for that policy.

questions.question: If a ring is covered by a specific jewellery policy and also under a general household policy, which policy normally responds first?
questions.explanation: The more specific insurance usually pays first.

questions.question: Subrogation in indemnity insurance most closely means:
options: The insured assigns all rights to any third party
The insurer steps into the policyholder’s shoes to recover from liable third parties after paying a claim
questions.correctAnswer: The insurer steps into the policyholder’s shoes to recover from liable third parties after paying a claim
questions.explanation: Subrogation prevents double recovery and helps keep premiums lower.

questions.question: Which policy normally does NOT give subrogation rights?
questions.explanation: Benefit policies are not contracts of indemnity; subrogation does not usually apply.

questions.question: Which case confirmed an insurer could, in principle, recover from a negligent fellow employee under subrogation rights?
questions.explanation: Insurers later often waive such rights by wording; many modern policies contain intra-employee waivers.

questions.question: A 'hold harmless' / waiver of subrogation clause agreed pre-loss will usually:
options: Have no effect on the insurer
Bind the insurer if permitted by policy terms or known to insurer
questions.correctAnswer: Bind the insurer if permitted by policy terms or known to insurer
questions.explanation: Policies often control or require insurer consent for waivers; otherwise, cover may be affected.

questions.question: A 'more specific insurance' clause mainly affects:
questions.explanation: It gives the specific policy primary liability before general cover responds.

questions.question: The sharing of a loss between two insurers covering the same interest, subject-matter and peril is called ________.
An insurer pursuing a negligent third party after paying the insured is exercising the right of ________.
A building worth £500,000 is insured with Insurer X for £300,000 and Insurer Y for £200,000. Both policies cover fire. Following a fire that causes £100,000 of damage, how much should Insurer X pay?
questions.explanation: Contribution applies. Insurer X has 3/5 (£300k/£500k) of the total cover, so they pay 3/5 of the loss: (300,000 / 500,000) * 100,000 = £60,000.

questions.question: When an insurer pays for a total loss claim for a car, what is the insurer's right regarding the damaged vehicle?
options: The insurer can take ownership of the salvaged vehicle.
The insurer must pay the policyholder for the salvaged vehicle.
The insurer has no rights to the salvaged vehicle.
The insurer must repair the vehicle, regardless of cost.
questions.correctAnswer: The insurer can take ownership of the salvaged vehicle.
questions.explanation: When an insurer pays a total loss claim, they are entitled to take ownership of the salvage (the remains of the property).

questions.question: A property owner was paid by his insurer for fire damage, but then also received the full, undamaged sale price from the buyer. What principle, established in Castellain v. Preston, allows the insurer to recover the money they paid?
questions.explanation: Castellain v. Preston is a key case for subrogation. It confirms that the insured cannot be more than indemnified. After paying the claim, the insurer is entitled to 'step into the shoes' of the insured and take over any rights they have to recover the loss from another source, preventing the insured from being paid twice.

flashcards.definition: For contribution to apply: 1) Two or more policies of indemnity must exist; 2) Common insurable interest; 3) Common peril; 4) Common subject-matter; 5) Each policy must be liable for the loss.
Insurers share losses in proportion to their sums insured, unless modified by wording.
A policy term that disapplies contribution for that policy.
Specific policy responds before general policy where both cover the same risk.
Authority that subrogation can (in principle) apply against a negligent co-employee; often waived by modern policies.
Agreement not to pursue recovery; may bind insurer if permitted by policy terms/consented.
Subrogation typically does not apply to benefit policies (e.g., personal accident).
The residual value of a damaged item after a total loss claim has been paid. The insurer is entitled to the salvage.

The cornerstone case for subrogation, establishing that an insured cannot recover more than a full indemnity. It gives the insurer the right to benefit from any recovery the insured can make from a third party for the same loss.

This case (North British & Mercantile v. Liverpool & London & Globe) established that for contribution to apply, the insurable interest must be common. A warehouse owner (bailee) and a grain owner had different interests, so their insurers could not contribute.
